image.altText: A close-up head and shoulders shot of Linda Reynolds arriving at court in Perth wearing glasses and a black jacket and top.

props.synopsis: The first day in the high-stakes trial in the WA Supreme Court has seen Linda Reynolds lawyer pick apart several claims by Brittany Higgins after she reported being raped in Parliament House.

title.children: What we learned from the first day of Linda Reynolds' defamation trial against Brittany Higgins

image.altText: A man stands next to a woman.

props.synopsis: Northern Territory Police Commissioner Michael Murphy has delivered an apology to the Indigenous community at the Garma Festival, acknowledging there have been times when NT Police did not protect Aboriginal people from harm. Look back on our blog of the day's events.

title.children: NT police commissioner 'deeply sorry' for years of injustice for Indigenous people — as it happened

image.altText: A small child dancing in the sand with adults watching in the background.

props.synopsis: Amid shifting sands in Indigenous affairs, young leaders are drawing strength from their culture to stand firm.

title.children: Young leaders growing in stature as sands shift in Indigenous leadership

image.altText: Australian Tara Rigney rowing in the women's single sculls at the Paris Olympics.

props.synopsis: Australian Tara Rigney misses out on a podium finish in the final of the women's singles sculls, while Jason Day remains in touch with the leaders at Le Golf National. Follow live.

title.children: Tara Rigney misses out on rowing podium, and it's moving day in the golf in Paris

image.altText: croweater on hill

props.synopsis: Australia joins the list of worldwide locations where Active Clubs have been established. Experts say white supremacy groups like this are a threat to our social cohesion.

title.children: Not sports clubs: 'Active Clubs' are threatening social cohesion in Australia, expert says

image.altText: Buildings in the backdrop, next to a Lebanese flag flying in Beirut.

props.synopsis: Australians in Lebanon say they've been left "stranded" trying to exit Lebanon amid renewed advice from the federal government to evacuate the country. But many say they've been left in the dark after being told the airport is closed.

title.children: 'Stranded' Australians holidaying in Lebanon say they can't get home amid evacuation orders

image.altText: A woman delivering a speech.

props.synopsis: Kamala Harris secures the delegate votes needed to clinch the Democratic US presidential nomination and become the first woman of colour at the top of a major party ticket.

title.children: Kamala Harris secures delegate votes needed to become Democratic nominee

image.altText: Police station shot up in flames

props.synopsis: Protesters attack police and start fires in Sunderland as violence spreads to another English city following a stabbing attack in Southport that left three children dead.

title.children: Protests turn violent in England as unrest spreads after Southport killings

image.altText: Jim Chalmers blue room

props.synopsis: This week's inflation numbers have spared the Reserve Bank — and the indebted — the spectre of another rate rise. But it hasn't made the problem go away — for the bank or the government.

title.children: Inflation isn't as bad as predicted, but we're now stuck at an inflection point on monetary policy

image.altText: Riley Thilthorpe of the Crows reacts after kicking a goal, punching the air in celebration

props.synopsis: Geelong have blown a 22-point lead to find themselves behind against the Crows heading into the final quarter of their crucial round 21 clash. Follow live.

title.children: Crows threatening major upset to give Geelong's finals hopes a huge blow

image.altText: A composite image of a man in a puffer jacket, skiers, and a foot in socks over a fire

props.synopsis: The word on the street seems unanimous — it feels like one of the coldest winters in living memory.

title.children: Australia shivers through June and July, so was the BOM's forecast of a warm winter wrong?

image.altText: A rugby league team celebrates a try

props.synopsis: St George Illawarra will take a narrow advantage into the second half as they look to spring an upset on the high-flying Storm. Follow live.

title.children: Dragons take shock lead into second half as Storm short-circuit

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Match report: Titans run riot to end Brisbane's season from hell

image.altText: Two young Indigenous boys in reflective, wrap-around shades sit on a bench and pull rap poses.

props.synopsis: A group of young Broome artists have been nominated for a National Indigenous Music Award, with mentors hoping it'll inspire other children in town.

title.children: Kimberley kids win national recognition for hip hop video

image.altText: An excavator sinking into mud at a mine.  A large dozer is being used to drag it out.

props.synopsis: The 48-year-old was working at the Byerwen surface coal mine this morning near Glenden in the Bowen Basin, about 200 kilometres west of Mackay.

title.children: Worker dead after accident at coal mine in north Queensland

image.altText: A man with a white shirt

props.synopsis: US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin has revoked a plea deal agreed to earlier this week with the man accused of being the chief architect of the September 11 attacks, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, and two of his accomplices, reinstating them as death penalty cases.

title.children: Pentagon chief revokes plea deal with three September 11 attack suspects, reinstating them as death penalty cases

image.altText: A man stands in a glass box as people take photos of him.

props.synopsis: One of the largest and most complex prisoner swaps since the Cold War was almost derailed by a shocking death, competing global agendas, and a US president's fading political ambitions.

title.children: A painstaking, top-secret prisoner swap was almost done. Then came a mysterious death

image.altText: A black sign with 'CFMEU Victoria' written on it, hanging on a construction site.

props.synopsis: Construction bosses and building industry whistleblowers fearful of retribution will be free to speak out against the CFMEU under cover of a potential parliamentary inquiry amid concern existing workplace regulators lack investigative teeth and protections.

title.children: Fair Work takeover of CFMEU 'not enough' say critics calling for greater witness protections

image.altText: 5qhfri

props.synopsis: On a day where the spotlight was on Australia's Saturday morning gold rush, there was drama and excitement elsewhere at the Paris Games. Here's the quick hits and bits you might have missed.

title.children: Olympic quick hits: Solomon Islands marathon runner competes in 100m, tiny nation secures first-ever medal, and Flavor Flav helps out

image.altText: A painting of a bearded man on wood.

props.synopsis: ABC Radio Brisbane asked its listeners to enter portraits of Costa Georgiadis for this year's Bradley. There were so many masterpieces he was relieved he wasn't a judge.

title.children: We asked you to capture Costa's bearded beauty – and here are our favourite artworks

image.altText: Anna at her gate close crop

props.synopsis: Anna reached adulthood believing she was an orphan. Then the truth came out.

title.children: 'I believe I was human trafficked': this Melbourne woman discovered her history was a lie

image.altText: hands holding Australian cash notes

props.synopsis: New data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics shows household spending has fallen by 0.5 per cent for June after two consecutive rises.

title.children: Australians households are spending less. Here's what they're cutting back on

image.altText: Colourful tins, jars and boxes on a kitchen pantry shelf.

props.synopsis: You may be eating Australian-grown food that has been processed overseas and then shipped back again. Local food manufacturers worry they will struggle to compete with imports among price-conscious consumers.

title.children: Exporting fresh food and importing it back processed — is this the future of Australian food?

image.altText: Saya Sakakibara holds her head and cries

props.synopsis: Saya Sakakibara has endured things as an athlete that many would ever recover from — but her Olympic gold medal is a testament to her strength, and that of her entire family.

title.children: The happy tears of Sakakibara's Olympic gold are a testament to her endurance in the face of adversity

image.altText: A young Yazidi woman holds up a photograph of herself and her older brother carrying a teddy bear and smiling.

props.synopsis: A decade after the Islamic State attempted to ethnically cleanse the Yazidi minority of northern Iraq, refugees in regional New South Wales struggle to rebuild their lives and preserve their culture.

title.children: Yazidi community's struggle to hold onto its culture 10 years after genocide at hands of ISIS

image.altText: Large entrances and cut-outs open the home up to the garden outside.

props.synopsis: The home opens up into a lush backyard, providing relief from the Queensland heat while giving the feel of more room inside.

title.children: House of the Year winner proves bigger isn't always better, with room for family and work under one roof

image.altText: A tall blonde woman in a beige wrap dress surrounded by artworks: blue stacked totems and a brass wall hanging behind her

props.synopsis: Clementine Stoney Maconachie made her Olympic debut in the pool at the Sydney 2000 Games. More than two decades later, she's in Paris as an Olympian Artist.

title.children: Illness ended this Australian swimmer's career. Now she's at the Olympics as an artist

image.altText: A dog in an orange tutu

props.synopsis: Pet owners are sacrificing spending in other areas of their lives to afford luxury pet items as a form of escapism in the cost-of-living crisis, according to researchers.

title.children: Miss Mia the cavoodle has more shoes than her owner, part of a trend of spoiled pets

image.altText: People sit and lie on the floor of a military plane's cabin

props.synopsis: It's a war that has displaced 10 million, created famine and killed at least 18,760 people. Every member of the Sudanese diaspora in Australia has been affected by the carnage.

title.children: Five days in an apartment in darkness: How one Australian escaped Sudan's brutal civil war

image.altText: The Eiffel Tower lit up with the beach volleyball stadium in the foreground and a sunset

props.synopsis: Paris 2024 has embraced its most famous landmark in the most spectacular way, giving rise to one of the most iconic of Olympic venues.

title.children: 'This is a spectacle': Athletes and celebs flock to one of the most iconic venues in Olympics history

image.altText: Five girls standing in e-sports uniform.

props.synopsis: After almost 10 years of competing as a "part-time, non-sponsored, zero-budget" team, Grills Gaming shares what it is like to push forward in the male-dominated arena of esports.

title.children: 'Oh my God, you can't lose to her': What's stopping women from making it to the top ranks in esports?

image.altText: Pool (1)

props.synopsis: In 2020, three childcare workers took six children on their weekly excursion to the pool – but only five made it home. A five-day inquest has probed how one toddler was left behind at a public swimming pool.

title.children: Alone and locked in a public pool, Kumanjayi drowned in minutes. His family wants answers

image.altText: Two men sit inside a stone cave as other people look in from a small doorway.

props.synopsis: The 2,500-year-old mummy — dubbed the Screaming Woman — was "virtually dissected" by an Egyptian research team.

title.children: Unknown mummy may be frozen in time 'screaming in agony' due to post-mortem spasm
